vibiom.name: Vibiom
vibiom.description: Vibiom is an autonomous AI development platform that transforms software specifications into production-ready applications through coordinated multi-agent orchestration. The full platform features 15-20 specialized base agents (product management, architecture, security, frontend, backend, testing, DevOps, etc.), with users able to generate custom agents on-the-fly for specific project needs. A built-in agent marketplace allows users to share and monetize specialized agents they've created.
vibiom.monetization_strategy: SaaS Subscription with Tiered Plans and Agent Marketplace
vibiom.problem: Solo developers and small teams want to build ambitious products but can't afford full engineering organizations. Existing AI coding tools (Cursor, Claude Code) help write code faster, but they're single-agent assistants—you still do all the architecture, security review, testing, and coordination yourself. More autonomous tools like Devin and Replit handle simple tasks but fail at complex, production-grade development because they lack specialized expertise. No tool gives solo developers the coordinated capabilities of an entire engineering team.
vibiom.solution: Vibiom is an AI orchestrator that coordinates specialized agents to build production-grade software—and it's being built to eventually improve itself. Starting as a CLI tool with three agents (Product → Backend → Security), it proves that multi-agent coordination produces better code than single-agent systems. Each agent specializes in one domain, validates previous work, and hands off to the next agent through structured workflows. As the system matures and proves reliable, Vibiom will dogfood itself—using its own multi-agent coordination to add features, expand capabilities, and refine its orchestration.
target_audience: Solo developers wanting to build complex products without a full engineering team
Small startups needing to rapidly prototype and iterate on software ideas
Freelance developers looking to scale their output and take on larger projects
Tech-savvy entrepreneurs aiming to launch software products with minimal coding
Development agencies seeking to augment their teams with autonomous AI agents
vibiom.mission_statement: Vibiom exists to prove that coordinated AI specialists can build better software than single AI generalists—and to build itself using that same coordination. Solo developers shouldn't choose between autocomplete tools that make them faster coders and autonomous agents that produce mediocre code. Our mission is to demonstrate that specialized AI agents, each expert in their domain and working through peer review, produce production-grade code that single-agent systems can't match.
vibiom.success_milestone: Vibiom successfully orchestrates 5-8 core agents to build a complete backend API (authentication, CRUD operations, database schema) from a written specification with minimal human intervention, completing the project in under 24 hours
vibiom.tagline: Multi-agent development that actually works. Built by using itself.

devgauntlet.name: DevGauntlet
devgauntlet.description: DevGauntlet is a comprehensive professional software engineering training platform where developers build real projects by completing Jira-style tickets—no tutorials, just requirements and automated testing. Starting with backend development (authentication, APIs, databases), DevGauntlet expands across the entire engineering stack: frontend frameworks, mobile development, DevOps practices, AI engineering, desktop applications, and CLI tools.
devgauntlet.problem: Most developer education focuses on tutorials that hold your hand through every step, leaving developers unprepared for real work where you get a ticket, research solutions, and ship tested code. Bootcamps teach syntax but not professional workflows. Junior developers struggle to prove they can work independently because they've never practiced taking requirements and delivering working software.
devgauntlet.solution: DevGauntlet teaches professional development by having you do professional development. You receive Jira-style tickets with requirements and acceptance criteria. You research, implement, and test your solution. Automated testing validates your work. Your completed projects prove you can work professionally from day one. Learn TDD, BDD/DDD, Docker, Kubernetes, CI/CD, and Agile workflows by doing what professional engineers do.
target_audience: Self-taught developers wanting to learn professional workflows
Bootcamp graduates needing to prove they can work independently
Junior developers preparing for their first engineering role
Career changers building a portfolio of real project work
Developers wanting to expand into new domains (backend, DevOps, AI)
devgauntlet.mission_statement: DevGauntlet exists because tutorials don't prepare you for real work. Our mission is to train developers the way they'll actually work—by taking tickets, researching solutions, writing tested code, and shipping. No hand-holding, no step-by-step guides, just the challenge and the tools to figure it out.
devgauntlet.success_milestone: 15 developers sign up and complete at least one full backend project challenge (MVP phase)
devgauntlet.tagline: No tutorials. Just challenges. Build like a professional developer, not a student.

scopecreep.name: ScopeCreep
scopecreep.description: ScopeCreep is an automated testing platform for PostgreSQL Row-Level Security (RLS) policies. Similar to APIsec's approach for API security testing, ScopeCreep continuously validates that database access controls work as intended by testing RLS policies against realistic user scenarios. It identifies misconfigurations, permission escalations, and data leaks before they reach production.
scopecreep.problem: Row-Level Security in PostgreSQL is powerful but notoriously difficult to test correctly. Developers define RLS policies assuming they work, but misconfigurations often go undetected until a data breach occurs. Manual testing is tedious and incomplete. There's no automated way to validate that RLS policies actually enforce the access patterns you intended.
scopecreep.solution: ScopeCreep automates RLS policy testing. Developers define expected access patterns (user A should see their own data, admin B should see everything, user C should see nothing), and ScopeCreep automatically generates test cases, runs them against your database, and alerts on violations. Continuous testing catches regressions when policies change.
target_audience: Backend developers using PostgreSQL RLS for multi-tenant applications
Security engineers auditing database access controls
Startups using Supabase who rely heavily on RLS
Development teams needing to validate access controls in CI/CD
Compliance-focused organizations requiring proof of access control testing
scopecreep.mission_statement: ScopeCreep exists because database authorization is too critical to test manually. Our mission is to bring the same rigor of API security testing to row-level security—automatically validating that your database access controls actually work before misconfigurations become breaches.
scopecreep.success_milestone: 3 companies pilot ScopeCreep and identify at least one RLS misconfiguration they weren't aware of
scopecreep.tagline: Automated RLS testing for databases. Catch authorization bugs before they reach production.

openorbit.name: OpenOrbit
openorbit.description: OpenOrbit is a project-focused social platform for tech professionals to build, design, and learn in public. Unlike LinkedIn's resume-centric approach, OpenOrbit centers on active projects—developers, designers, security professionals, and other tech creators share their works-in-progress with status updates, images, videos, and documentation.
openorbit.problem: LinkedIn is resume-focused—your profile is about where you worked, not what you're building. Twitter/X is noisy and not structured for project updates. There's no dedicated platform for tech professionals to share their building journey in a structured way that connects them with collaborators and builds reputation through work, not credentials.
openorbit.solution: OpenOrbit makes 'building in public' the core social experience. Users create project profiles with milestones, get feedback from the community, find collaborators, and showcase their building process. Projects can be shared externally, building reputation through transparent progress rather than polished portfolios. Connect with people through what you're creating rather than where you work.
target_audience: Indie hackers and solo developers building in public
Designers sharing their design process and getting feedback
Security researchers documenting their work
Open-source maintainers engaging with their community
Tech creators who want to be known for what they build, not where they work
openorbit.mission_statement: OpenOrbit exists because your best work isn't a resume bullet—it's what you're building right now. Our mission is to create a social platform where tech professionals connect through active projects, not past credentials. We believe reputation should come from transparent progress and real work, not polished portfolios and job titles.
openorbit.success_milestone: 100 users create accounts and post at least 3 project updates each, with measurable engagement (comments/feedback) on their posts
openorbit.tagline: Build in public, together. A social platform for tech creators sharing projects, not resumes.

instapi.name: InstAPI
instapi.description: InstAPI is a rapid API prototyping tool that lets developers spin up mock REST APIs instantly for frontend development and testing. Define your endpoints and response shapes, and InstAPI generates a working API you can hit immediately—no backend code required.
instapi.problem: Frontend developers often block on backend APIs that aren't ready yet. Setting up mock servers is tedious. Existing tools like JSON Server require local setup. There's friction between needing an API to build against and waiting for the real backend to be ready.
instapi.solution: InstAPI lets you define API endpoints and response schemas in a web UI, then instantly generates a hosted mock API you can call from your frontend. No local setup, no code, just define and use. Great for prototyping, demos, and unblocking frontend development.
target_audience: Frontend developers needing mock APIs for development
Full-stack developers prototyping before building real backends
Teams with frontend and backend working in parallel
Developers building demos or proof-of-concepts quickly
instapi.mission_statement: InstAPI exists to unblock frontend development. Our mission is to eliminate the wait for backend APIs by letting developers instantly create the mock APIs they need to keep building.
instapi.success_milestone: 50 developers use InstAPI to create mock APIs for their projects
instapi.tagline: Mock APIs in seconds. Stop waiting for backend, start building frontend.
